Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Flow and Rheology of Particle-Fluid Suspensions with Variable Hydrophobicity

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1067598
PI: Utter

The rheology of granular and granular-fluid systems is of significant current interest. While many studies focus on the jamming and flow of particle-fluid mixtures, there has been little work on the effects of surface chemistry, such as the relative hydrophobic or hydrophilic properties of the grains. In addition to the relevance of surface chemistry in soil mechanics and industrial problems, such as effects on erosion, water runoff, and filtration, hydrophobicity also provides a control parameter on the effective cohesion of grains. Recent applications of the jamming phase picture to colloidal systems with attractive interactions are related examples of the importance of grain-grain interactions mediated by surface properties.
This Research at Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) proposal aims to systematically study the effect of the hydrophobic interactions in both the well-characterized rotating drum geometry and jamming behavior in flow through a constriction. Rheology and dynamics are studied in systems (i) that vary by fraction of hydrophobic grains and (ii) that are submerged in solvents of different polarities to tune the importance of the surface chemistry effects. This set of experiments has direct relevance to surface chemistry of soil particulates that impact soil/water interactions. In addition, these samples can be submerged in fluids of different polarity to control the relative importance of the surface chemistry effects. The preliminary data show both a strong tendency of hydrophobic grains to segregate from water and a decreased response when submerged in a relatively non-polar liquid like isopropanol or hexane. Known particle/solvent systems relevant to work on colloidal stability will be used and then extended to miscible fluids of different polarities which will allow fine-tuned control of the effective cohesion between hydrophobic grains. We will quantitatively measure the effective hydrophobicity and correlate these with flow properties such as angle of repose, jamming probability, segregation effects, and rheological shear strength.

A final objective related to the broader impacts of this proposal is the scientific training of undergraduate research students in a highly interdisciplinary research environment. This project will directly involve the training of up to six undergraduate researchers over the duration of the program, but it is expected that up to ten will likely be impacted including unpaid research for credit during the academic year. In addition, we plan to hire a high school teacher for the summer of year 2, in order to continue one of JMU's missions of educating teachers. The students will be exposed to issues in materials science and complex systems, including rheology, dynamics, and image processing. The participants in this program will be expected to participate in activities related to the NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) sites in chemistry and materials science at JMU to become part of a "community of scholars" with over sixty other summer undergraduate researchers in chemistry and materials science at JMU. In summary, this program helps serve to broadly impact the pipeline of future scientists from the high school through the graduate level with students trained in cutting-edge research in multiphase flows.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project is to characterize the rheology of hydrophilic/hydrophobic granular mixtures in suspension. These are materials composed of individual grains, like sand, in which the surface chemistry tends to repel water. While flow of dry granular materials and granular-fluid suspensions have received considerable attention over the past couple decades, little is known about the effects of surface chemistry on the flow, aggregation, and mixing of suspensions. This is despite the fact that hydrophobicity, or water repellancy, can by significant in both natural and industrial granular samples. For instance, soils with organic coatings and clay components and industrial pharmaceutical buffers can have hydrophobic surfaces, impacting, flow, erosion, and processing techniques. Specifically, we aimed to perform experiments on samples of a known concentration of hydrophobic grains, with the balance being hydrophilic grains to elucidate the flow and rheology of these samples. Surface tension effects specifically leads to cohesion and aggregation that is the focus of our studies. 

 

Specific experiments performed focus on the rotating drum geometry, which allows measurements of aggregation and segregation in a sample that is confined in a cylindrical drum which rotates to induce continuous flow, as well as flow through a constriction. We also measure contact angles for water droplets on the granular substrate to characterize bulk hydrophobicity and stress/strain relationships using a commercial rheometer to quantify stress-strain relationships. Though soil hydrophobicity has received significant attention, the present experiments allow us to control in detail the concentration of the sample used as well as the spatial pattern in some cases. Additional experimental geometries, described further below, aim to characterize related properties of erosion patterns of samples and impacts of hydrophobic granular jets in water. These serve as additional tests of rheological properties and make direct connections to prior experiments in geophysics and fluid dynamics.

 

Based on results from the rotating drum, the importance of the aggregation process itself became apparent as, once formed, aggregates are stable over extended experimental times. This combined with experiments on the flow of hydrophobic samples submerged in water through a constriction led to a focus on characterizing aggregation in a stream of hydrophobic granular columns into water. This allowed us to understand the initiation of aggregates and the entrainment of air, determined to be a critical issue for the resulting surface tension effects and stability of the aggregates, in a controlled manner analogous to the many experiments on fluid jets. Similar to fluid experiments, the dynamics are interesting both in that they determine the aggregation behavior and are sensitive tests of materials parameters.

 

Specific goals included the following: 1. Characterize aggregation and mixing in the rotating drum geometry with changes in hydrophobic concentration, including aggregate formation and stability/dynamics of the interface. 2. Determine flow properties through a constriction, analogous to prior experiments on hopper flow in dry granular materials. 3. Determine the role of concentration, sample size, and air entrainment on aggregate formation via a hydrophobic granular jet in water. 

 

The experiments described above resulted in a number of key observations: 1. Even at concentrations as low as 7.5%, the sample is non-wetting, leading to stable aggregates and preventing mixing. 2. The effective surface tension determines the size of aggregates formed, with larger aggregates observed at larger hydrophobic concentration, but aggregate formation depends greatly on details of the experimental history. 3. The stability of a slope depends on the effective tension via the hydrophobic concentration as well as aggregate size, in cases where aggregates are present. 4. Hydrophobic granular streams entering water exhibit a number of instabilities observed in other fluid systems, including droplet formation and a shear instability.

 

As very few controlled experiments have thus far been performed on the rheology and dynamics of hydrophobic granular samples, these results are significant in understanding the mechanisms and effects of surface tension in the interaction of hydrophobic samples and water.

 

As a Research in Undergraduate Institutions proposal, the grant supported a total of seven undergraduate collaborators in performing conducting cutting-edge research and gaining valuable analysis skills. All students disseminated research by presenting a talk or poster either at an internal symposium or at a national meeting, gaining additional skills in communicating science. All but one of the students who have graduated continued to pursue research by attending graduate school or seeking employment in a field closely related to physics.
